p.s: Gatsby is the main character in the novel The Great Gatsby and shown as a rich and weathywealthy man trying to impress his former lover with his weathwealth.

In a world full of materialistic pursued, sucesssuccess and weathwealth, the world of old money, Gatsby symbolises the new money since he did not earn his weathwealth through his family but through the down world buisnessbusiness.
He seems to be very confident and always sure about himself, knowing what he's doing.
That is why his behavior in the given excerpt is so untypical for him.
The reader knows, the real purpose of the big parties and the big mansion is to impress Daisy.
Since five years he has been trying to catch her attention, which shows how obsessed he is with his dream of a life with his former lover.
This is also shown by the symbolism of the clock falling.
Gatsbyaccidentlyaccidentally knocks a clock over and catches it before it could hit the ground and break (p. 85, ll. 5-7).
This can be seen as an attempt of Gatsby to stop the time and retrieve the past.
The fact that the time stopped at a specific point in time refers to Gatsby being trapped, chasing a dream of ideal love with Daisy.

Whereas Daisy has moved on and married another weathywealthy man, Gatsby holds on to the past, even counting the time, which is made clear when he knows the exact amount of time since they had last seen each other (p. 85, l. 17).
Nick then considers the clock as an old one (l. 12) which leads to the old times.
In comparison to the previous chapters, this is the first time the reader experiences Gatsby's vulnerability and uncertainty.
Nick describes his distraught eyes (p. 84, l. 30) and the usually confidently talking Gatsby seems very unsure of himself by muttering and whispering in a miserable way (p. 89, l. 31).
Additionally, his body language also shows how unsure of himself he is.
As already mentioned he clumsily knocks over the clock.
His eyes are delieverdeliver an impression of what he feels like, when Nick mentionesmentions his tragic (p. 84, l. 16), distraught (p. 84, l. 30) and unhappy (p. 85, l. 25) looks.
Another hint for his apparent restlessness is that he keeps trembelingtrembling (p. 85, l. 6).
The given excerpt can be devideddivided into two parts because or a radical change of atmosphere.
When Nick comes back into the living room Gatsby's nervous tension seems gone and by the exaggeration of using glows (p. 84, l. 14) a vivid image of Gatsby's happiness is created.
Furthermore, the division is created by the change of weather of the setting.

Because of the rain Gatsby could act like he was looking for safety of the rain at Nick's and make it seem like a coincidence that Daisy was there too as if he hasn't been waiting for this moment for the past 5 years.

Later on in the chapter, when the rain created mist, the vision is limited so Daisy can't see her house from the balcony, meaning she is far away from her life with Tom and her child but in this moment with Gatsby.
And when the significant rain stops and Nick comes back to the room, any sign of embarassmentembarrassment seems gone with Gatsby's uncertainty.
Another sign for Gatsby being himself again is that he started adding his typical old sport again after addressing Nick (p. 87, l. 16).
After this change, Gatsby gets to his original plan of impressing Daisy with his mansion, his clothes and boasting about his wealth.
Because of the first person narrative perspective of Nick the reader gets an impression of his thoughts about the situation.

He mostly seems annoyed with Gatsby (It wasn't a bit funny) (p. 84, l. 19), espaciallyespecially when they talk outside of the living room and Gatsby, panicking, repeats what a terrible mistake it was, Nick forgets his usuallusual respectfullrespectful, admiring behavior towards Gatsby by calling him a little boy and rude (p. 86, ll. 8-9).

Besides that, another scene where Nick seems critical towards Gatsby is when Gatsby tries to let Nick earn money through one of his buisnessesbusinesses, but Nick expects it has something to do with illegal affairs and rejects (p. 81, ll. 21-29).

This regards Gatsby's tactlessness, how far out of touch he really is from the old money world he is trying to or pretending to be a part of and now he rewards Nick with money instead of something of sentimental value.
After this chapter Nick is more sure in his suspicion that Gatsby is not honest about the way he earned his money and his past.
On page 88 in ll. 5-7 you can see that Gatsby's sayings do not add up and when Nick specificlyspecifically asks in what buissnessbusiness he moves he does not tell him straightly.
A further scene referring to Nick's annoyance is when Gatsby shows them around his house by listing the things they were to see with the repeated use of and (p. 90, ll. 25-26).
One of the most important symbols in the novel is the green light, mentioned in the end of the chapter.
It symbolizes Gatsby's dream his love for Daisy in his attempt to make it reality.
He reaches towards the green light because of his love for Daisy and when he fullfilledfulfilled that dream by being reunited with her this ritual of his has lost it's meaning (p. 91, l. 9).
The green light can also be seen as the American Dream and the pursuit of happiness and weathwealth, but once you have fully reached your goal you could lose your purpose in life.
In conclusion, the excerpt shows a totally diffrentdifferent side of Gatsby, pure and revealing, which allows the reader to have an insight into his character.
The fact that he fell out of his role because of Daisy reveals how important that dream of his is for him and how he trystries through the value of materialism to be rich of love.
